review_title: Stability and growing pains with digital transformation
pros: Stable company with a good growth outlook. Friendly staff worldwide with some interesting projects ongoing. There are quite a few talented people within the organization. It's very well known company in France and Europe, and offers opportunities worldwide. I have worked in 3 different geographies so far in the past 10 years. The company is doing a lot now to embrace digital transformation and build an entrepreneurial spirit (start-up culture).
cons: Strong francophonic culture can sometimes be an impediment to growth. Understanding the French culture and also the language is considered a plus to progress, though this is never made explicit. The culture is also prone to making a subject complex before a decision to proceed, which also emphasizes the company's careful and methodical approach. Not a dynamic, gung-ho type approach. Also slow to adapt to the ongoing digital transformation, though they are making an effort to catch up. HR is almost non-existent and relationships matter a lot, fitting with the first line of this write-up (French knowledge).

review_title: Morale very poor at Balazs NanoAnalysis division
pros: This is an OK company to come to straight out of college, but not for long-term career development.  Most employees get a decent amount of instrument time and a chance to learn some analytical techniques.  Only a few employees work weekends.  Employees I know in other parts of Air Liquide are happy with their jobs.
cons: Pay is well below average.  Management does not get along within their own group.  Employee morale is low and turn-over is high.  Recently employees were instructed at a company wide (Balazs) meeting to not use bandaids from the company first aid kit for any injuries incurred away from work.  This pretty much sums up the attitude of the local management towards employees.

review_title: Negative experience at underachieving company (in U.S.)
pros: Industry technology leader, high potential for investment in innovation, above average benefits for the industry, good engineering mentoring programs, excellent R&D facilities
cons: Very political, outdated infrastructure / systems, bureaucracy & processes which are difficult to manage. High attrition in certain business areas. Several managers appear to have been chosen for pedigree over relevant experience & people skills. Managers rotate through positions in 3 years or less leading to short term decision making with shallow focus on P&L and stock price with no consequences for poor results after they have left the position. Line employees disconnected from long-term vision. Poor assimilation of acquired businesses into parent company (diminishing their prior potential).  HR department suffers from high turnover and seen to be ignorant or downright dismissive of lower-line employee issues

review_title: Pathetic work culture- Unprofessional and rude people-No Teamwork
pros: Getting some extra income if one is willing to compromise on one's talent and self-esteem.
cons: No teamwork, people are not smart, management itself compromises on data quality by reporting wrong results to Clients, forcefully making the QC pass by wrongly processing the data and not taking time out to troubleshoot the problem. Some stupid people working here long-term are highly reluctant to making any improvements in automating the processes etc. and if smart people try to improve the processes and making them more efficient, their mouth is shut by everyone. Even the management supports the dumb folks who have their monopoly here. I would not advise smart people to work here. If you only want to earn few extra dollars (they don't pay that well too) and do not have any other option for income and can do work that is a no-brainer and even a high-schooler can do, and dont open their mouth at all to make any improvements, just quietly accept and do what is being told to do even if it is wrong, then that kind of a person can survive here for sometime. No scope of career growth.

review_title: Have you ever worked for the French?  Never again.
pros: You will learn a great deal about the technology, and they have a very cordial social "European" culture.  There is some training budget, and travel budget as well.  I enjoyed my weekends in Paris and Germany.
cons:
One challenge is getting approval from France on everything, because the experts there are always out on holiday, or at a plant, or at a conference.  I could do nothing without their approval.  And if your project is late because of it, you will suffer the consequences, not them.
Another is the low, low salary range, with no OT pay, and working 7 days a week to keep up the work load.
Project managers are always right.  Even when they are wrong.  And way too arrogant to admit they are wrong.  And completely unwilling to hear your side of any story.

The hardest part of the job was knowing that the fat cats in the corporate office had no clue how many evacuations we had. They never had to experience something like that. If you are young with a masters degree, Air LIquide will love you, although their hiring based strictly on this basis has often back fired on them.  There is high turnover within certain divisions.

review_title: Look out if you are over 40.
pros:
Good company, and many departments are a great place to work.  If you are getting up in age, beware because they don't care about your tenure, loyalty or how much service you have provided.  They will take advantage of you if you don't know your rights in the workplace so be sure to drop by a bookstore for employee rights book.  You will need it. Calculate your own pay.  This company swindle me out of $15,000 for 3 years because I was misclassified as exempt
Violates Federal Law and they did this willfully so they wouldn't have to pay overtime.  Management in some departments lacking ethics and will do almost anything to cover up their lousy skills.  HR is worthless.  All, I can say if you are smart you may survive, but keep your eyes open, read all company policies, and make SURE you read everything you can about the company.  Check your deductions and pay regularly because they can't add..
cons: Management is poor and the company is low on ethics.  Look out if you are an older worker and make sure you check your check.  They will screw you for the almighty dollar.

review_title: A behind the scenes company that affects everyone's life.
pros: Air Liquide promotes from within the ranks.  Your career is only limited by your ambition and desire to learn.  Air LIquide is a financially conservative company, as such weathered the economic melt down and came out ahead with an increase in profitability over the previous year.  Air Liquide empowers their employees to make decisions and usually supports those decisions.  It is a great place to work and have a career not just a job.  The customer base and uses for their product are diverse and cover the entire spectrum from a small mom and pop operation to multi-million dollar refineries.  Air Liquide has a profit sharing plan called Goal$hare that is usually worth about 4% of your base salary.
cons: There are eight business units or entities that make up Air Liquide America.  Each is operated and behaves like its own company.  If you do not have a degree or an MBA your advancement is limited.

pros: Good health benefits, decent pay, encourages work-life balance, excellent 401K match with extra matches for tenure.  Local management is great and our direct chain up to corporate is one of the best.  Opportunity to advance if desired.
cons: Hard to get a pay increase once you start, if you don't get it at offer it will adversely affect you the entire time at the company.  Don't fall for promises to make it up "later", if it's not in writing it won't happen and even then it may not be honored.  Too many changes happening at once right now.

job_title: Engineering Manager in Frankfurt am Main
pros: Large company with sound business model, subject to only moderate economic fluctuations. (Caution: This applies to Air Liquide Group as a whole. Specific business areas face severe economic fluctuations!) Career development is promoted and interesting career opportunities may arise, provided you are capable to extensively network with (particularly the French) decision makers, and are willing to change location internationally every 3 to 5 years. Employee share program in many countries.
cons: Decision making is tedious and complex due to the matrix structure of the organization and the global scale of many decisions. In project environments, project managers are rarely equipped with the necessary decision-making power to successfully manage projects. Depending on the work area, vertical career paths might be limited, if you are not ready to move (with your family?) every 3 to 5 years. Expat conditions are mediocre, but having the right sponsor may help. Same is true for international business travel.

job_title: Anonymous Employee in New York, NY
pros: I've been with the company for nearly 2 years and have been very impressed with the way the management and the company in general tries to treat everyone like an individual and take their personal needs and circumstances into account.  Senior management is very approachable and responsive to inquiries from all levels and this approachability continues down to the local management level as well.  Issues are always responded to timely and suggestions for improvement are always welcomed and reviewed for feasibility regardless of whether or not they are acted upon.
cons: Given the layers of complexity to the business and the need for many divisions, departments, and specialists it is easy to create silos based on expertise.  It can become easy to get isolated in a silo and feel disconnected from the corporate entity and lose sight of the big picture.  However, there are multiple resources both in terms of personnel and shared online information to minimize this.

pros: Excellent on-the-job learning platform for fresh grad engineers. Most technical managers and senior engineers are good mentors and great at getting you up to speed to perform your typical responsibilities. Being an international company, technical support from global counterpart is available when new challenges are encountered and yet to experience locally.
cons: High level positions are paid at high salary, at the expense of very low salary for junior employees. Junior staff turnover rate is high to meet competitive package offered by other firms or industries.

review_title: Many Pros & Cons in the Middle East Region
pros: Great global leading group with a various business and much to learn in a unique industry.  and a great add to any resume and professional career.
cons:
The main down side is that the entities in the middle east is almost disconnected from Air Liquide global culture. with a lack of long-term strategic business decisions, that force the group to let many young professionals during those frequent changes and firing. 
HR support in the region in terms of mobility and assisting staff to secure other position in the group almost doesn't exist.  
Workload assessment is never taken in consideration in the reorganization decision making.

pros: Youre able to get a lot of experience in the first 5 years of your career that would likely take longer to get at other companies. Most of the people here are friendly and willing to help each other out espicially in the pipeline zones.
cons: The corporate office culture is very different than other areas of the company. Some groups there seem happy and are able to achieve work\life balance but others are miserable.  Managers are often promoted from technical positions and are unlikely to have the personality for being a great manager. A lot of time is spent on non high value added activities in certain departments and can be frustrating to high performers.

pros: Air Liquide has a healthy company culture.  It is a financial powerhouse with strong business models tailored to the markets it serves.  It's long-term perspective helps to ensure the health of the business long into the future.  It is generally risk averse, with the exception of development of its people.  It moves people into leadership position outside their comfort zone which allows for quick growth and results in well rounded leaders.
cons: Steady business sometimes leads to a lack of urgency in decision making ... if we aren't the first mover, that is okay ... we will win in the end.

review_title: Not the company it once was
pros: Solid company that is unlikely to go out of business. Operations management cares about  the employees. Outstanding safety record.
cons:
It is ironic that the company wants to use glassdoor to "attract and retain" employees not long after a fairly large reduction in force. I used to feel like a company but after the changes over the last few years if feels like any other part of corporate America. The company is no longer loyal to the employees. 
This year about half of the employees didn't receive a raise this year, and the average for those that did is 1.5%. This comes off the heals of a year where we made our financial targets. After the purchase of Air Gas if feels like we are being brought down to their level of benefits so I expect this level of compensation increases to continue for many years.

review_title: You won't find a better local driving job
pros: Good money - I don't think you can do much better as far a local driving jobs go, great 401(k) match, good benefits, plenty of vacation and sick days.  I've had good experiences with all of the managers I've worked for.  Very serious safety culture.
cons: You need to be somewhat computer savvy to work with the electronic onboard computers in the truck.  There are cameras in the trucks.  They are very serious about the safety culture, so you if you want to work here you'd better buy into it.  There are LOTS of rules and you need to be willing to follow them or you will not be employed for long.

pros: In certain locations, coworkers will be willing to help with your project no matter what it is.  When I started here, I received no direct training from my manager and had to learn a lot on my own as well as from my coworkers.  Aside from that, Air Liquide claims that there will be plenty of opportunities for upward movement as long as you perform well.  I have yet to experience that with the little time I have been employed.
cons: In my particular situation, my direct manager has not spent much time with me to develop my skills.  This is not his fault though, as he is swamped with plenty of projects.  There is no one that is assigned to train me in particular systems.

review_title: Learning ground for ChE and MechEng

The training was great and the coworkers are kind and intelligent. There is no seniority. You can get promoted if you are competitive enough.
cons: It is hard to get promoted if there are no slot for higher position. The work Is a little bit boring since it is routinary.

review_title: You have got to be kidding me
job_title: If I Told You, You Would Fire Me
pros: You get a paycheck and the pay can be good. Some good people still left ... for now.
cons: Support organizations act as if the plants exist for them. Workload is insane and there is no one to help you unless you want MORE audits. Safety department is out of control with changes that they push down to the field with no support.  Far too many changes without any training. Can't pay their bills now and vendors won't work anymore because they didn't staff and ERP program swap properly. BTW - all the people on the Oracle project are getting promoted despite its abysmal failure.

pros: Decent training and good place to build 'portable' skill sets.  Salary and benefits are seem to be on par with the industry.  Jobs are incredibly stable.  Phantom options are a nice way of keeping people if your one of the few to get them.
cons: AL hasn't announce a major 'new' investment in a very long time.  It is understandable that higher level jobs are filled from France (being a French company) but I don't understand why Canadians seem to be the preferred management stock.  Attrition is very high and I'm seeing talent leave in droves.  People who are left behind seem to be those who aren't wanted elsewhere.

pros: Great opportunities to work overseas and on interesting projects
cons: It's still a French company through and through, no matter what country you are in, and all the real major decisions are made by French executives and they can be very opaque about why and how they make those decisions.  There is a real reluctance to adopt local country best practices or decision making in either the line businesses or in the support functions (e.g. finance, IT, HR, etc.).  It's frustrating.  Also, there is a great stigma against failing, even if it's well thought out and a calculated risk.  It is far better to aim modestly and achieve modestly than it is to aim high and take a risk and succeed greatly and also fail on occasion.  A failure can be a scarlet letter that often cannot be erased from your career reputation here.

review_title: Good company, needs a little polishing
pros: Excellent co-workers, terrific work/life balance, good benefits, great 401k
cons:
Employees are somewhat in the dark when it comes to Senior Leadership decision making.  While it has improved over time, it still needs a lot of work.

Needs much better training for essential job tools such as new software packages, equipment, etc.  Often times new tools are released to employees in the field and they are given little to no training to use these tools properly.  Therefore, said employees use a great deal of their time figuring out how to do their job rather than doing their job.

pros: Dedicated employees, great benefits, challenging work, fair.
cons: More process oriented than results oriented; being headquartered in Paris adds to the bureaucracy; not very collaborative at the business unit level

review_title: I'm proud to say I work at Air Liquide!
pros:
Air Liquide really cares about their employees and does its best to continually promote from within. As an employee you're able to drive your own career and you have the ability to try new opportunities based on your interest, skills and performance. If you're mobile, those career opportunities are unlimited. 

The culture is also great - it's like having a large extended family and everyone genuinely cares about one another. Air Liquide also has a flex work schedule so it also allows you to have a work/life balance that meets your needs.
cons: Things tend to move a little too slow at times based on needing so many internal approvals or sometimes due to lack of empowerment to employees from Management.

job_title: ALLEX Program Participant in Houston, TX
pros: The Air Liquide ALLEX Program provides many opportunities for college graduates to explore different job opportunities early on in their careers. This sets up the participant for future success by allowing them to develop a strong network within the company by working in different entities that you would not have to opportunity if you were directly hired.
cons: The only cons that come to mind are the limited availability for the ALLEX during the program in term of geographical preference. For example if multiple ALLEX participants want a particular position, only one will be chosen for that 6 month rotation.

review_title: Not living the dream, but a good stepping stone.
pros: Renumeration is very fair, and they have some amazing employees.  Opportunity to move around and grow is good. Lots to learn. Middle management is pretty good across the board.
cons: Upper management in the West region is atrocious.  Bullying is rampant,  and the work culture reflects this. GM promotes a locker room atmosphere and next to no promotion of team mentality or cooperation between departments is done.  Company has many internal system, process, and communication issues and nothing is  made easily accessible or clear.

review_title: Air Liquide will only gain mediocre employees if it continues to pay and stay technologically mediocre.
pros: Wonderful benefits!  Good overall company structure.   Work/Life balance is good.
cons: Working with old systems that continue to have "patches" that never fix the main problem.  Difficult to find movement within the company.  Company seems to have trouble promoting good employees quickly which in turn will cause employees to leave (high turnover).

review_title: Little Opportunity for Advancement Except for a Select Few
pros: Air Liquide comes off as a very caring company.  The benefits such as medical, dental and retirement are in line with the rest of the industrial gas industry.
cons: The company is still 'the good old boys club'.  Only a select few see any type of advancement.  No matter how much education an employee gets or how hard they work, the rewards are only seen by the minority of the company.  Extremely low morale.

review_title: Upper management is "OUT of Touch" with what is important to their employees.
pros: Great benefits, great people, great locations and good equipment.  Had a great manager!
cons: Upper management leaves their middle management hanging "Out to Dry" and when they need support it is easier to turn their backs than manage up.  Frequent promises and no action.  Poor decision making by upper level management.  Says one thing and then does another.  To many changes at one time makes work difficult.

pros: Generally friendly helpful work atmosphere. Easy to find the resources you need and people are generally good about getting back to you. Stable. It is a great place to learn engineering and project management.
cons: The disconnect between what management says and does can be frustrating at times. The company tries to run very lean at the manufacturing/plant level so the operators/blue collar workers are overworked and there is never enough money to repair/replace all the part that need it, particularly on the 40 year old plants. That can be a bit depressing.

pros: The company is very stable and prefers an approach of slow steady growth year after year.  401k matching benefits were the best I have experienced. 4% match to start, 5% after one year, 6% after 5 years, and 9% after 9 years of service.
cons: The company is very conservative and takes a very long time to make decisions.  The lack of decisiveness often places the company behind it competitors when it comes to new technologies and processes.  Communication between management and employees on goals and direction is slow, vague, and sometimes not shared at all.

job_title: Production Technician in North Branch, NJ
pros: The Air Liquide Advanced Materials  site I work at has a good work culture. Management does listen to employees input and multiple changes have occurred from such interactions. The quality of personnel is quite good and most have a good "team work" attitude. Lots of prior Military personnel work here and it shows in how we operate. Efficient, safe and with superb quality.
cons: Management does listen to employees but at times can be a little slow to react or deploy changes once agreed upon. Site I work at is cramped for space making menial jobs sometimes more time consuming. Training needs to be more thorough across the board.

review_title: A Great Experience! I only left because I wanted to go to an African country where Air Liquide is not present.
pros:
- Working on middle size projects: Large enough to be interesting and have an impact on the industry landscape, and Small enough to be aware of the progression of the whole project and be involved in it.
- Very caring managers and "human" atmosphere. 
- Safety is the absolute priority and it is felt in the office and on the site.
- Stable business model, therefore good opportunities to evolve vertically and geographically.
cons:
- Some very hard and complex projects when it comes to absolutely new technologies.
- The salary is slightly below the average of Engineering market.

pros: A few very nice contractors
cons: I recently resigned after 1 1/2 years and had a front seat to the chaos in this company. The HR department is the worst ever...poor management, overworked recruiters, rotating contractors in the business every other month, poor onboarding process, hiring freezes, constant turn-over and the new HR director has 30-45 days career management experience. A director with 6 people reporting to them sounds like a manager to me. The entire management team resigned and the employees under them were promoted into available positions instead of hiring outside the company. I would never recommend this company as they are terribly behind in technology as well as compensation.

review_title: Don't join unless you live in Houston
pros: Good people at the operations level. More good managers than bad ones.  Good career opportunities and advancement for chemical and mechanical engineers who have the ability to advance to leadership and are willing to relocate.
cons: The acquisition of Air Gas coupled with a downturn in the business has created some financial difficulties. All career paths lead to Houston, the HQ for the Americas Zone.  If you aren't willing to move there eventually,  think twice before joining.  Promotions can at times be very political. This is becoming more and more common.  HR, with the exception of recruiting, is populated by people who seem to have little interest  in the business or the employees.

pros: Very rarely are employees micromanaged, and if so, the reason is usually because the manager in place is new to the group or recently promoted. There are numerous opportunities abroad if you would like to be come an expat.
cons:
From a technological standpoint (employee experience) the company is several years behind. Much of the software and work processes are outdated and can cause for very frustrating experiences. Base compensation is average/below average and perks are practically non existent. Maintaining the status quo is very much preferred.  

Perhaps the biggest con is how achievement is recognized: if one appears to bring results you will be rewarded as such. A high performer is one who management most recently remembers during the annual review process.

review_title: Air Liquide is an OK company.
pros:
The "Air" business is a fairly stable industry (unlike oilfield).  Layoffs are almost non-existent.
There is a decent work/life balance.
Flexible hours are permitted.
There is a very strong commitment to Safety.
cons:
Compared to other companies and averages in Houston, the salaries are below the line.  
There is a horrible lack of organization at all levels.  Each group/division/country does everything "their way" which causes confusion between groups/divisions/countries.
Politics are ridiculous (unless you're French)
Change or new ideas are not accepted well.
There is very high turnover.  The typical employee tenure is 3 years or less.

pros: I thought they were a great company that really took care of their people, until they sold us all down the river.
cons: Getting forced into AirGas. Air Liquide bought AirGas and gave half of their people to AirGas, a bottom-feeding retail outfit that seems to have implemented a three year plan to run us all out and replace us with cheaper workers. 20+ years as a loyal Air Liquide employee and now I lose my retirement and can't afford the crazy expensive Airgas benefits, so I have to start all over again somewhere else.

review_title: Literally the best job and team I ever had
pros: During my time on the HR team at Air Liquide, I received phenomenal support and mentoring from my Director, Manager and colleagues. review_title: Exciting Job at a Large Company

1) Because of the nationwide and international reach of the company, expect to do a lot of traveling or relocation throughout your career unless you plan to stay in a local job without big advancements. 2) Lack of follow up on action items from certain groups is still common in the company, no accountability if those groups don't follow through.

3) Since centralizing many corporate function in Houston, a lot of responsibilities have been pushed to the already overwhelmed operation sites. Corporate doesn't have a clue what's going on in satellite operations. Managers are expected to know and stay on top of so much more corporate details on top of running the operation. 

4) Some newer employees have come in wanting to make changes, and some become disgruntled after not getting feedback or not seeing the changes as fast as they hoped for. It's a large company afterall, and many old-timers are used to the way work processes go.  Unless we get upper management push, and then they monetarily incentivize the rest of the employees to push for change, it's hard to make certain changes.

review_title: Room for growth, but managable if you have patience
pros:
Once you get in the right group or with a competent manager, and if you have enough patience, Air Liquide is a reasonably good place to work. Most managers are pretty good about letting employees take vacations /doc appointments when they need to (I've only worked for 1 manager that controlled that tightly). There are several really good leaders and managers in the company. Networking is very important to go to places you really want. 

Most people, including those outside of your department are willing to take the extra step to help you if you're nice. If you're not a confrontational person, you'll be fine. Diversity at corporate is good. Most people try.

There are a lot of career options for you if you're willing to move around, within the US or out. Houston always has job openings. Company is pretty stable and layoffs aren't that severe compared to some of our customers. If you're in good with your manager and your work is good, the company can usually find you a job (even if its in another city) during heavy layoffs. They want to promote within and keep their people. People stay a long time.
cons:
If you end up with a bad manager (e.g. micro-managers, unresponsive, or unexperienced etc.) then it can really make your job and life miserable. Confrontational people or "challengers" have not been seen to last in this company either. 

The company runs with the leanest teams and runs with bare minimum, at good times and bad.

Air Liquide has generally good policies, but enforcement is not strong in most procedures written, so short-cuts to by-pass perceived unimportant processes are common. It can also be a training issues where newer employees are not taught (or imporperly taught) some processes  and had to learn everything on the job. "Training" is now signing off on your 100+ documents on time, of which 40% of them may not even apply to your job. 

Human resource additions are slow. Idea-to-result projects and approvals move slow in general, unless you are willing to babysit each step to complete any task. Bureaucracy has been getting worse by the year (possibly due to the perception that people aren't following policies, so more policies are written to try to cover the loopholes).

There are some people that don't get recognized for their efforts and therefore become disgruntled, especially those that try to make do because others have by-passed policies. Management has tried to make programs to enforce recognition by peer compliments but it has been seen as superficial because some people aren't working that hard and still get on the recognition page, maybe due to politics. 

Too many teams are resistent to reform and work smarter instead of harder. Passivity is rampant. These extremes make the ultimate dynamics between teams need a lot of patience and post-change results are mediocre at best.

review_title: Terrible Management, Terrible Leadership, Terrible Citizenship
pros: They pay you as little as they possibly can to keep you alive. Honestly they don't really care about you
cons:
Where do I start...
Starting from the middle/upper management (managers/directors), no one really knows what to do. With exception of the wonderful few, their days start at 10am, end at 4pm, with an hour or two of managers-only lunches. No one really cares about including fellow interns and analysts. A quote from a manager, "Throw more of you interns at me? Please no. I have enough troubles". They really don't even know what they are looking for. They overload you just so you can maybe crank out something useful they can take credit for. They call it "responsibilities".

Did I mention they pay you as little as possible? They even emphasize that during their recruiting process - "If you want to make money, Air Liquide is not the place for you. But if you want a company that cares about its work, this is the perfect place for you". Basically, you get paid minimal of the industry so you could applaud yourself when you dig a diamond out of their workload. Guys, if this company can hire you, try any other company in the industry you are gonna get hired. Your salary will be higher, and they will actually care about you. Heck, why is a business intern's salary 5% lower than an engineer intern's when they both doing business work? The irony.

Down to the ALLEX Program, us interns call it the program for people who don't know what the heck they want to do when they grow up. They put you on 6 month rotations through different businesses. Sounds great! You are just a 6 month intern at different places, nothing more. You will have no expertise, no solid connections, no stable family and friends, and you must decide by the end of your second year rotation. Here's a piece of advice - your time is better spent in a 1-2 year graduate program then come out to work for Microsoft, Deloitte, Shell, or whatever it is you prefer. 

What about the full-timer staffs? This area is the complete opposite of the middle management folks - most people are cool, with the exception of a few bad eggs that could really tick you off. To the upcoming interns and full-timers, this is what you call office politics. People start talking behind others backs, and the suck-ups start siding with the managers. If you think they aren't talking about you, they probably are.

Unlike most companies Air Liquide does not believe in support for success. A worthy employee should be someone who can make money for nothing, and that's it. In last year's round of interns, a good number of them were disengaged due to whatever reasons. In response, instead of helping them out, they were ignored and weeded out by the end of the intern class. Even those who stayed engaged had a hard time. It's one of those "you either do it or can't do it” type of hostile environment.

Last thing, professionalism. Just kidding, there is none. If they don't like you (which doesn't take too much, like most children), they will plant actions and events to build cases against you for everyone to see. I remember this one intern's boss asked him to crack jokes during his presentation to make it "fun and interesting" to management. His boss also asked him to put in a random graph that he didn't understand in the end because his boss insisted. Poor kid didn't even see it coming - he got slammed on by the last graph during his presentation, and got ridiculed for his joke.
